page.title: 10ST. MARTIN'S IN 1985 (2)
page.content: The farms are still there, the parish being an agricultural strong- hold: a bastion against the ever- increasing threat of attack by the seemingly insatiable appetite of a growing population for land on which to live.{(Jersey has a population of {almost 80,000 on only 45 square miles {of land).} St. Martin's parish has a geographical position that favours the early cropping of potatoes, Jersey's principal export, and thus in the island's battle between agriculture and land developers the farmers here still have priority. The leafy lanes are still there, but the number of vehicles using them has greatly increased. Care has to be taken as these narrow lanes were not created with modern-day traffic in mind.
